content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my preference for avoiding risk, security, and predictability, I would lean towards the option that guarantees a steady income with minimal losses. In this game, picking 'B' results in earning 40$ in every round when my opponent also picks 'B', which happens 50% of the time (as 'R' is picked half as often). On the other hand, when I pick 'B' but my opponent picks 'R', I lose the opportunity to earn 15$. Since my opponent could potentially be any player with varying strategies, it is hard to predict their actions.

However, over 75 rounds, my strategy of picking 'B' would still likely result in a higher total income due to the majority of rounds being won (where both players pick 'B') and minimizing the losses when my opponent picks 'R'. Thus, I would choose {B} for this game.
